As with a lot of CS stuff, a lot of explanations will take this thing that's fairly obvious on its face and turn it into an essay with scientific notation that you need 4 years of college to understand, when an example is so much easier for everyone
...you should instead create a Dog class that only barks, and the two sub classes of WildDog and TrainedDog (or whatever)

e.g. you have a class of Dog, and you give it the methods bark and rollOver. You shouldn't have something inheriting from this class that CAN'T rollOver. So you shouldn't make a class of WildDog, that inherits from Dog and removes the rollOver functionality. If you need a WildDog that can't rollOver

It's a premise that's very easy to understand, but that people have (seemingly on purpose) made difficult again through jargon

Basically, if you have a superclass, you should be able to substitute it for anything that inherits from it, and the program won't break because a property is undefined

Then you'll understand they're hesitant to say "definitely" ever. I can't think of a case in which banning that word would lead to a situation where some world leader wants to make an account but his name contains the word, but I can't rule out the possibility. Thus I say "probably"

I'm a programmer, that's how we talk
The account was taken down less than an hour after it was first reported tho

I am a programmer, and, yes, you can probably safely ban all uses of THAT word. But you can't do it with the short f-slur, you can't do it "negro," you can't do it with "groomer." Any blanket bans need to be considered and thoughtful and even then they won't be fully effective

I don't know how you expect to filter those things out programmatically. If you see someone calling gay people "groomers" then you need to report it, but no program is going to be able to read through a skeet and say "they don't have proof for their claim"

No, I'm not missing the point. I agree that such names are offensive and wrong. What I'm saying is that no filter is going to be effective, and they were relying on community reporting and moderation, which worked. The account was taken down in less than an hour, which is faster than any other site

That's not what whataboutism is, but what I'm trying to point out is that, yes, not blocking the word outright is an oversight, but blocking the word outright doesn't fix your problem in any meaningful way

Okay, but that's another word that's hard to filter out, because variations of the word mean something else in other languages. That's why it was removed from the filter. If these names are offensive, report them. Any solution that works is going to need community reporting
I guess I would argue, if the filter caught the full word, but allowed in "IHate(the word without an e)" would that be better?
We do

I just showed how blocking it in plaintext IS a hard problem. It's a three letter word. Screennames are often words strung together AND have to account for proper names and foreign languages. There are 116,000 people with the last name "Fagundes." Blocking that string is HARD
Wow! Really?

And the issue is that, with slurs like the f-slur (one that's of particular impact to me), blocking it ends up blocking a bunch of names that aren't offensive (CliffAguirre, to name one off the top of my head). It requires a human touch, which is what they had in place already

Sure. But blocking it and it alone is effectively meaningless. Even the fix put in place by volunteers wouldn't have caught this instance, because it had an "s" at the end. And even if you just block anything with THAT slur in it, there's a hundred other slurs out there
You always know just what to say

I don't think it should be pointless. I'm on your side. I also want a site free from Nazis, where all my queer friends can be awesome and queer together. I think that site is this one, and I want to keep us all here

This also WASN'T basic shit. Building an effective, meaningful filter for offensive screennames is hard. It's nearly impossible. Yesterday I got matched in Smash Bros with someone named L3t5_g0_br4nd0n_f4g. You think Nintendo hasn't tried to fix this problem? They really, really have
They said "it was our mistake." What do you want them to do?
Like, for real, do you think ANY of your options are better than here that made one (1) mistake and then took steps to fix it within 48 hours? Because I don't

Okay, fair enough, but what's your alternative? I'm trying to be pragmatic here. We either have Nazis getting tipped ad revenue, or we have Zuckerberg shoveling brands down our throats and disallowing nudity, or we have this place that's trying its best

And you can argue with those experts and say they're wrong, but all a company cares about is what makes them money. So either they're listening to people (right or wrong) telling them not to say "sorry," or they're so cartoonishly evil they can't physically type the word. Which is more likely?

I mean, think about it for a second. If you have a company, that doesn't care about you, and there's no reason for them NOT to issue an apology, why would they not issue a fake apology? That'd be the easiest thing in the world. They don't do it because experts tell them not to
Lawyers who do tort law
Okay, object away, but this is in every comms textbook
Well, in fairness, Rush was playing

Yes, according to law friends

But more than that, comms people tell you not to do it. Saying sorry leads to headlines like, "Bluesky apologizes for allowing racism," which makes most people who read it focus on the "allowing racism" and not on the "apologizes"
Exactly
I'm not saying they couldn't do better, but the fact is that no solution is ever going to be perfect, and this weird app full of dicks and butts is the closest I've found so far

I don't wanna belabor this point but proper moderation was in place. The offending account was taken down less than an hour after it was first reported, which is far better than other social media sites that actually turn a profit

As a gay dev (of a different site, but still) I can tell you that blocking, for instance, the three letter f-slur in usernames is gonna be near impossible. Any effective solution is going to rely on community reporting and moderation, which Bluesky already has, and has promised to improve
When I was a young temp with no health insurance I let it go and it turned into scarlet fever <true-story.gif>

I think that's wise. Meaningful, effective change takes time. From their response (which I know took longer than people wanted, but was actually much faster than most companies), and from the past goodwill I have towards them, I'm, willing to give them a little leeway

I'm not trying to take away anyone's anger or hurt over the situation, but were I affected, I'd rather have action than the words "I'm sorry." Especially if the optics from that apology only serve to negatively impact new users to the point that the site goes under

I don't think that means marginalized groups get screwed over. I'm not a POC, but I'm imagining if the offending handle had the f-slur in it instead, and to me, in that situation, this is a good response
Not as messed up as "Exhibit A: photo of the bloody crime scene" will be

It's not just legal (although it's also legal) all communications handbooks tell you not to apologize. When you apologize, you get a bunch of headlines like "Bluesky apologizes for racism on site." This gets you headlines like "Bluesky vows to fight racism on site"
Our community guidelines reflect our values: that racism and harassment have no place on Bluesky, and we will continue to take action to uphold these policies.

No, sorry, to be clear: this won't even block the use of a slur in a name. This only checks that the username isn't ONLY a slur. In fact, it wouldn't even have caught the original offending account because that one used an "s" at the end

The change was actually put in by a member of the community (Bluesky is open source), although it did have to be approved by a mod

It's also barely anything. All it does is block these EXACT usernames from being created. You could still make a username like "ihatef-gs"

I'll be honest, it looks like they didn't spend much time on this reserve list. I think they were mostly just hoping to let moderation handle this kind of thing. Which is what happened in this case. The account showed up, it was reported, and now it's gone

An example that comes to mind, you'd wanna prevent a username like "beatthef-g" but maybe not "hellofaghost" (hell of a ghost). And you can't just ask new users to wait until a human being can review every single new handle

💯 

It definitely needs to be addressed somehow, but there's a lot of things to consider in building something like that, and I'm sure they don't want one dev doing it in the middle of the night. My guess is they were always just hoping to have it handled through moderators

It's not a filter. You can have a username called "jesus-fucked." However, the reserve list (that they copied from an existing one someone else had built) won't let you make a username that's JUST the word "fuck" because that's on the reserve list (that they didn't build)

That wasn't a filter for offensive words, it was a reserve list (basically a way to prevent people from creating accounts that might want to be used by the platform itself, like "customer-support"), and it was just copied wholesale from somewhere else

People are treating it like it's malicious on the part of bluesky, but it sorta just seems like an oversight. Obviously it needs to be fixed, but they have a small team and it's after work and they also probably have a lot to think about in the right way to build the filter
